msgSnippet: Thanks for the suggestions.  The responses at least confirm that this should not happen if all of my assumptions are correct. The

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Fwd: Re: [junit] Off-topic: How is ArrayIndexOutOfBounds possible?]
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: James Sinnamon <sinnamon@...>

Thanks for the suggestions.  The responses at least 
confirm that this should not happen if all of my 
assumptions are correct.

The ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException has happened only 
once that I noticed.  If it is due to a bug, somewhere
in class Vector or somewhere in the JVM or in some underlying
native method, then it won't be an easy one to find.

In the meantime, I will have to make an explicit check 
for the Exception, so that I don't inadvertantly miss it 
next time, and  also capture as much information as possible.

If it does occur again, I will try out the suggestions.

Thanks again.

regards,

James

> From: Mike Clark <mike@...>
> Subject: Re: [junit] Off-topic: How is ArrayIndexOutOfBounds possible?
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com

> Just to rule out the possibility that another thread is removing the 
> last element from the vector in between the isEmpty() and remove() 
> statements, you could explicitly synchronize the steps, as in
>
>     synchronized(inMsgQueue) {
>         if(!inMsgQueue.isEmpty()) {
>             msg = (SimpleMsg) inMsgQueue.remove(0);
>         }
>     }
>
> Just something to try...

> Mike


> Peter Spitz wrote:

> > The only thing I can think of is that the isEmpty() function is returning a
> > value of "false" even if the array is empty. I'd put in a test for that.
> > This sounds silly to me even as I'm typing it, but it's the best I can do
> > and maybe it will trigger some other helpful thoughts.  
> 
> > Peter
> > 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: James Sinnamon
> > Dear Junit Users,
> > 
> > Sorry for this off-topic message, but it is posible that someone may be
> > able to offer some useful advice:
> >
> > When I tested a program recently,  I got the error:
> >
> > java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: Array index out of range: 0
> >        at java.util.Vector.remove(Vector.java:806)
> >        at org.multipi.ActorMailSorter.run(ActorMailSorter.java:33)
> >        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:484)
> > 
> > ... it seems to be telling me that an attempt to remove element 0
> > of a vector, is causing a fatal error.  The code which triggered this
> > error is:
> >
> >      if(!inMsgQueue.isEmpty()) {
> >         msg = (SimpleMsg) inMsgQueue.remove(0);
> >        ...
> > 
> > .... where inMsgQueue is a Vector.  Now assuming that there are no other
> > Thread
> > processes trying to remove elements from the vector (and I believe this
> > to be the  case), should it be possible for this error to occur?  From my
> > understanding of  Vector
> > objects, this should not be possible.
subject: [Fwd: Re: [junit] Off-topic: How is ArrayIndexOutOfBounds possible?]
